reaction.primarysourcereaction: Hair loss, pale stools, sweating and nausea with a taste of decay
Pale stools, Massive pale stools / Massive foaming stools
Pale stools, Massive pale stools / Massive foaming stools
Nausea with a taste of decay
Nausea with a taste of decay

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
Case number PHHY2011DE32543, is an initial spontaneous report received from the other health care professional via a sales representative regarding a patient participating in the patient support program Sanservice (DE-SAS11-026SANSERVI) on 14 Apr 2011 with follow up report from a nurse received on 17 May 2011, from a nurse on 28 Sep 2011 and from a nurse on 28 Nov 2011 with further follow up received from a nurse on 16 Feb 2012, with further follow up information received from a nurse on 12 Apr 2012, follow-up nurse report received on 11 May 2012 with follow up report from a nurse received on 11 Jun 2012, follow up report from a nurse received on 18 Jan 2013: This report refers to a 58-years-old male patient. The patient had medical history of increased blood pressure, unspecified thyroid disease and arthrosis. The patient's concomitant medications included Atacand (candesartan cilexetil), Vigantoletten 1000 IU (colecalciferol) and L-Thyroxin (levothyroxine). The patient received treatment with Sandostatin LAR (octreotide with poly(d l-lactide-co-glycolide)) for acromegaly since 01 Oct 2010 at dose of 20 mg. On 14 Apr 2011, the last dosage of Sandostatin LAR 20 mg was received by the patient. On 18 Apr 2011, the patient started to develop diarrhea which was described as just only mild diarrhea and shaking attacks (like sugar shock symptoms) and problems with jaw. In addition, since Sandostatin LAR injection has started, the patient suffered from severe problems with haemorrhoids, which required a surgical intervention in hospital on 11 Apr 2011. On an unknown date, the patient developed hair loss, pale stools, sweating and nausea with a taste of decay. On an unknown date, one week after Sandostatin LAR injection (exact date was not provided), the patient had massive foaming and pale stools and strong nausea for about 1 week, these events were considered as non-serious. On an unknown date, after starting Sandostatin LAR the patient had renal pain due to kidney stones. The nausea was treated with pantoprazole. Last Sandostatin LAR injection so far was administered on 28 Oct 2011. On 22 May 2012, the patient was hospitalized for arthrosis surgery. After last injection on 22 Dec 2012, again extremely intense diarrhea, “2 times/month blood in stools”, intense nausea, nervousness, trembling and dizziness. Treatment with Sandostatin LAR was ongoing. The events other than hemorrhoids problems reported as non-serious by the nurse. The outcome for renal pain and kidney stones, massive pale stools / massive pale stools was not reported. The outcome was reported as recovered for hemorrhoids problems and condition unchanged for all other adverse events. The causality for events suspected kidney stones and renal pain was reported as not-suspected to Sandostatin LAR while causality of other adverse events was reported as suspected to Sandostatin LAR.
Follow-up report received on 17 May 2011: Onset for diarrheas, shaking attacks and jaw problems was reported as 18 Apr 2011. Action taken of suspect drug was added.
Follow up report received on 28 Sep 2011: Updated therapy start date (Sandostatin), new events, reported outcome and causality.
Follow up report received on 28 Nov 2011: The patient's concomitant medication was added. The information of suspect drug Sandostatin LAR was updated. The outcome of diarrhea, hair loss, pale stools, sweating and nausea with a taste of decay was updated.
Follow up report received on 16 Feb 2012: Updated seriousness of the event and new event (kidneys stones and renal pain).
Follow up report received on 12 Apr 2012: Patients weight was corrected. In addition, information regarding some events was added.
Follow-up report received on 11 May 2012: Updated patient weight, concomitant medications, medical history, event (diarrhea) related information and surgery.
Follow up report received on 11 Jun 2012: Updated event outcome (mild diarrhea).
Follow up received on 18 Jan 2013 from nurse: patient's weight updated. Events added (blood in stool, nervousness, trembling and dizziness). Outcome of the events updated.
summary.sendercomment:
Serious spontaneous report,
Haemorrhoids [hospitalisation], assessed as unlisted according to the Core Data Sheet. The information provided in this individual case does not warrant a change to the Core Data Sheet text. The topic will be monitored closely.
Diarrhea [medically significant], assessed as listed in the Core Data Sheet.
All spontaneous reports are considered suspected for reporting purposes or in accordance with national regulatory requirements.
MR: The information was considered inadequate to fully evaluate the case.
